summary: This document is an excerpt from a book titled 'Massage For Dummies' or similar instructional guide on massage therapy. It covers chapters on massage terminology, finding a massage therapist, rules for receiving massage, and techniques for giving massage. The content is purely educational and has no direct connection to the Epstein case.

persons.name: Johann Mezger
persons.context: Mentioned as a Dutch man who decided to use French words to describe massage movements.

persons.name: Zach Thomas
persons.context: A minister from North Carolina who became a massage therapist after a powerful massage experience and helped form the National Association of Bodywork in Religious Services.

persons.name: Dr. Ruth Westheimer
persons.context: Anecdote about the author massaging Dr. Ruth, who had difficulty climbing onto the massage table.

persons.name: Dan Ulrich
persons.role: Past President of Florida State Massage Therapy Association
persons.context: Mentioned regarding inclusion of license numbers in Yellow Pages ads reducing unethical massage advertising.

persons.name: Grace Apfel
persons.context: Created the Body Balancer massage device.

persons.name: Tom Myers
persons.context: Quoted on the human hand being an unparalleled massage tool.

persons.name: Wesley
persons.context: Mentioned as performing a massage with a Hawaiian invocation learned from his teacher Auntie Margaret.

persons.name: Auntie Margaret
persons.context: Wesley's teacher who taught him the Hawaiian invocation.

persons.name: José
persons.context: A patient with AIDS in a hospital ward who received compassionate touch from volunteers.

persons.name: Rob Boyte
persons.context: Volunteered with the author to touch José in the hospital.

persons.name: Greg
persons.context: A journalist friend who uses a Shiatsu massager for back problems.

locations: University of Miami Medical Center AIDS ward
keyFacts: This document is a general instructional guide on massage therapy with no relation to the Epstein case.
It includes detailed explanations of massage techniques, terminology, and professional practices.
The text contains anecdotes about various individuals receiving or giving massage in non-criminal contexts.
It discusses professional organizations like AMTA, ABMP, IMA, and NCBTMB.
The document emphasizes ethical practices, contraindications, and creating a proper massage environment.
